properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-03T06:38:32-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: southern, eastern, northeastern and parts of central Newfoundland. Time span: this morning until this evening. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will spread northward this morning. Snowfall accumulations of near 15 cm are expected in the south and east today with accumulations of 15 to 25 in the northeast and central before the snow begins to mix with or change briefly to rain. Rain is expected to be most significant in the south, where the Burin Peninsula could see 10 to 20 mm by the time precipitation tapers off this evening. Some localized flooding is possible in that area due to existing snow pack. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T23:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T08:45:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3071645406.2020
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-03T11:28:41-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected tonight. Wind chill values are expected to moderate on Monday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h from the northeast and northwest. Locations: Norman Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: this afternoon until Monday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to begin this afternoon before tapering off to flurries Monday morning in the Red Bay to L'anse-au-Clair area. Snow and blowing snow will continue until Monday evening in the Norman Bay to Lodge Bay area. The fresh snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow Sunday evening through Monday evening. Winds are expected to further strengthen Monday evening in the Norman Bay area when the winds shift around to northwesterly with gusts up to 100 km/h possible. Visibility is expected to be near zero along exposed areas of the coast during this time. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-03T06:55:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T14:56:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3730955820.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system is bringing heavy snow to portions of southern Manitoba this morning. Heavy snow will continue from the interlake to Bisset area this morning before tapering off. Snowfall totals of 10-15 cm are expected by noon Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A line of snowsqualls should move out of the area this morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T19:34:36-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: continuing until near midnight. Remarks: The combination of fresh fallen snow, already existing snowpack and falling rain will cause hazardous driving conditions and localized flooding in areas where water is not able to drain properly. Precipitation will quickly taper off near midnight tonight. However, temperatures will fall below freezing by morning. Expect icy conditions by Monday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-03T04:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T19:26:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3901725462.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter are high in the Greater Montreal Area and will remain so through Monday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-03T14:59:19-00:00

Further snowfall: 5 to 10 cm and potentially reaching close to 15 cm over northern Inverness and Victoria counties. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 70 km/h. Locations: Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County, Inverness County - Mabou and North, and Victoria County. Time span: until near noon. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow and blowing snow on Monday. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h Monday afternoon, approaching 100 km/h along the coast Monday night. Locations: Makkovik to Black Tickle. Time span: overnight tonight until late in the day on Tuesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin near midnight tonight before becoming heavy at times by Monday morning. Strong winds will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow beginning Monday afternoon. Poor conditions will persist through Monday night before gradually improving through the day on Tuesday as the snow and winds begin to ease. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 100 km/h along the coast. Locations: southern Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: this afternoon. Remarks: Southeasterly winds are expected to continue to increase today with gusts reaching up to 100 km/h along the coast by this afternoon. Winds will quickly subside and shift to southwesterly by this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
